diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, kidneys, brain, and joints. Symptoms go through periods of flare-ups and remissions.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that has features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can present with symptoms similar to SLE.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. Extra-articular manifestations can include skin, neurological, and hematological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Systemic features can include hematological abnormalities and neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body. Common symptoms include oral ulcers, genital ulcers, eye inflammation, and skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme
diagnoses.description: An acute, immune-mediated condition presenting with distinctive target-like skin lesions, often with mucous membrane involvement. It is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to certain infections or medications.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome that is caused by certain prescription drugs. Symptoms are similar to those of SLE but usually resolve after the causative medication is stopped.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenia. Patients may experience symptoms related to anemia and low platelet count.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that causes painful blisters and sores on the skin and mucous membranes, including the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Lupus-like Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that presents with symptoms similar to those of systemic lupus erythematosus but does not fulfill all the criteria for SLE. It can be idiopathic or induced by certain factors.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Cancer (e.g., lung cancer, breast cancer, lymphoma)
Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., Mixed Connective Tissue Disease)
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Epilepsy (in the context of systemic disease and CNS involvement)
Connective Tissue Disease (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
Viral infections (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV)
Schizophrenia (in rare cases, can present with somatic symptoms)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Cancer (various types, including lung cancer and lymphoma)
Infectious diseases (e.g., viral or bacterial infections can lead to symptoms mimicking autoimmune disorders)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g., Celiac Disease, Inflammatory Bowel Disease)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue that normally lines the uterus grows outside the uterus. This condition can lead to dysmenorrhea and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
diagnoses.description: An infection of the female reproductive organs. It may cause dysmenorrhea, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: Includes conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, and it can be associated with increased immunoglobulins and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in affected organs, including increased immunoglobulins and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. It may cause abdominal pain and hypoferritinemia due to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can increase immunoglobulins and cause systemic symptoms such as leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells due to a lack of iron, leading to hypoferritinemia. It may also cause dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms may include dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infection typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). It can lead to increased immunoglobulins and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease in which the body’s immune system attacks the liver, possibly causing increased immunoglobulins and leukocytosis.

diagnoses: Functional gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Irritable Bowel Syndrome - IBS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative colitis
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and fever. The increased immunoglobulins indicate an abnormal immune response, which is common in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. Symptoms include joint pain, fatigue, and muscle pain, with increased immunoglobulins due to an autoimmune reaction.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause joint pain, muscle pain, and chronic fatigue. Increased immunoglobulins are often found due to the body's immune response.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms include fatigue, difficulty in focusing vision, muscle pain, and mood changes.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It does not typically involve increased immunoglobulins but shares several symptoms with the described condition.

diagnoses.name: Polymyalgia Rheumatica
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness around the shoulders and hips. The exact cause is unknown, but it may involve abnormal immune responses.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease that exhibits features of several connective tissue diseases, such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include high levels of immunoglobulins, muscle pain, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms may include muscle pain, joint pain, and mood changes.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: The overproduction of a hormone by the thyroid. Symptoms can include muscle weakness, mood lability, and sometimes increased immunoglobulins due to the body's immune response against the thyroid.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by feelings of anxiety and fear. Anxiety can cause physical symptoms such as chest pain and difficulty focusing, as well as mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: COPD is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: IBS is a common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Patients often report sensitivity to chemicals.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex chronic disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders of the immune system that cause recurrent infections and increase susceptibility to infection. These disorders can be primary (congenital) or acquired.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Also known as hay fever, it causes cold-like signs and symptoms, such as a runny nose, itchy eyes, congestion, sneezing, and sinus pressure. Can also exacerbate wheezing in asthma patients.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of your esophagus.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity (MCS)
diagnoses.description: A condition where people have severe reactions to various environmental chemicals, pollutants, or irritants. Symptoms can be similar to other illnesses and may include wheezing and difficulty breathing.

diagnoses: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) - for infertility in females

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common viral infections can lead to symptoms like nausea and lymphadenopathy as the body's immune response activates.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Specific bacterial infections can cause both localized issues such as sinusitis and periodontal disease and systemic reactions like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Can contribute to sinusitis and lymphadenopathy due to the spread of infection and immune system response.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, leading to symptoms such as lymphadenopathy, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Dental Abscess
diagnoses.reasoning: An abscessed tooth can cause periodontal disease and may also lead to lymphadenitis due to infection spreading.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily causes nausea but can also lead to lymphadenopathy as the body fights the infection.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause generalized lymphadenopathy and, in later stages, can lead to nausea and other symptoms due to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This parasitic infection can cause lymphadenopathy and occasionally leads to symptoms such as nausea.

diagnoses.name: Strep Throat
diagnoses.reasoning: A bacterial infection that can cause swelling and tenderness in the lymph nodes (lymphadenitis) and might be associated with sinusitis due to proximity.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects tear and saliva production, leading to dry mouth (which can exacerbate periodontal disease) and might also cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by non-restorative sleep and difficulty focusing, this syndrome might not directly cause thrombocytopenia, thromboembolic disease or osteopenia, but systemic inflammation and immune dysfunction can link to these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
diagnoses.rationale: Autoimmune disorders can lead to a wide variety of symptoms including non-restorative sleep and vision issues due to associated Sjögren's syndrome, thrombocytopenia from immune-mediated platelet destruction, thromboembolic events from antiphospholipid syndrome, and osteopenia due to chronic inflammation and corticosteroid use.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A disorder characterized by the body's immune system mistakenly attacking certain proteins in the blood, leading to thromboembolic events. It can also be associated with thrombocytopenia and secondary issues such as osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: This deficiency can contribute to osteopenia and generalized muscle weakness or fatigue, which might explain non-restorative sleep. It typically doesn't directly cause thrombocytopenia or thromboembolic diseases but may contribute to an overall pattern of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause fatigue resulting in non-restorative sleep, and indirectly lead to osteopenia through hormonal imbalances. Complex relationships with autoimmune thyroiditis could contribute to thrombocytopenia. It is not typically associated with thromboembolic disease directly.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.rationale: A condition directly causing non-restorative sleep which can lead to systemic inflammation, potentially contributing indirectly to conditions like thromboembolic disease. Correlations with osteopenia are less direct but could be linked through associated conditions or medication side effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to thrombocytopenia due to splenic sequestration or decreased thrombopoietin production. Liver disease can also cause fatigue and cognitive symptoms due to altered ammonia metabolism. Associations with osteopenia come from malabsorption and vitamin D deficiency, while thromboembolic risk increases with coagulation disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Associated with thrombocytopenia due to uremic platelet dysfunction, chronic anemia leading to fatigue and non-restorative sleep, and osteopenia through disturbances in calcium and phosphate metabolism. Thromboembolic events may occur but are less directly connected.

diagnoses.name: Cancer (Specific Types e.g., Hematologic Malignancies)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers can lead to thrombocytopenia either due to bone marrow involvement or treatment effects. Cancer-associated thrombosis is a well-established phenomenon. Non-restorative sleep might result from general fatigue or pain associated with cancer, while certain treatments can contribute to osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.rationale: While more known for neurological symptoms, it can cause fatigue and non-restorative sleep. There's a less direct link to osteopenia through mobility issues and vitamin D metabolism. Visual symptoms are a hallmark. Thrombocytopenia and thromboembolic disease are not typically direct symptoms but could arise in complex clinical scenarios.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes (irritated eyes), dry mouth, and can lead to decreased immunoglobulin production and systemic complications.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that affects the immune system's ability to fight off certain infections. Patients may have decreased immunoglobulins and can experience various infections that can lead to granuloma formation and potentially fibrosis.

diagnoses.name: Hyperlipidemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by elevated levels of lipids in the blood (dyslipidemia), which can lead to atherosclerosis and other cardiovascular diseases.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs. Host Disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: Occurs in some patients after bone marrow or stem cell transplant; it can lead to fibrosis in various organs, decreased immunoglobulins due to immune suppression, and can affect the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can lead to dyslipidemia and may sometimes be associated with fibrosis.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder of the liver that leads to destruction of the bile ducts, potentially causing fibrosis of the liver. It can be associated with dyslipidemia and decreased immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It is characterized by the formation of granulomas, leading to fibrosis, and can present with eye symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the eyes (leading to irritation) and the immune system, potentially resulting in decreased levels of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects mostly the lungs and digestive system, leading to fibrosis in these organs. While primarily diagnosed based on pulmonary and digestive symptoms, it can have systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus Type 2
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Diabetes can lead to dyslipidemia and may contribute to the development of certain types of fibrosis.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Hypertension or fluctuating blood pressure conditions

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Immune Deficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: Characterized by a decrease in one or more types of body's immune system components leading to increased susceptibility to infections. Can explain decreased immunoglobulins and potentially contribute indirectly to other symptoms due to infection or inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the blood doesn't have enough healthy red blood cells, can cause restless legs syndrome, dyspnea, and could be linked to osteopenia due to its effect on bone density.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a buildup of toxins and impurities in the blood, which can cause symptoms like restless legs syndrome. It can also contribute to anemia, bone density issues, and altered immune responses.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that can lead to decreased immunoglobulins after prolonged disease or treatment, osteopenia from both chronic inflammation and potential glucocorticoid therapy, and can occasionally cause secondary Sjögren's syndrome, which could explain some of the dyspnea if associated with interstitial lung disease.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells that can cause decreased immunoglobulins (specifically, an increase in a monoclonal protein at the expense of other immunoglobulins), bone pain and osteopenia due to lesions, and dyspnea could be related to anemia or kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can contribute to restless legs syndrome, can decrease immunoglobulin production, affect breathing and cause dyspnea, and also contribute to bone density loss.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Can cause iron deficiency anemia leading to restless legs syndrome and osteopenia due to malabsorption, and can also affect immune system function.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect exocrine glands but also systemic manifestations including peripheral neuropathy (potentially tied to restless legs), decreased immunoglobulin production, and dyspnea if associated with lung involvement.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: While primarily known for its impact on blood sugar levels, long-term uncontrolled diabetes can lead to complications such as peripheral neuropathy (related to restless legs), increased susceptibility to infections (potentially explaining decreased immunoglobulins), and impacting bone density.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins such as B12, folate, or vitamin D can lead to a wide array of symptoms including restless legs syndrome, increased susceptibility to infections, osteopenia, and potentially dyspnea due to associated anemia.

diagnoses: Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and Bone Disorder (CKD-MBD)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck
Gorlin Syndrome (Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome)
Chronic Hepatitis B or C infection
Autoimmune Diseases such as Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to thrombocytosis, enlarged lymph nodes, and various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer that originates in the lymphatic system. It may cause symptoms like lymphadenopathy, intermittent fever, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms can include enlarged lymph nodes, chest pain, and systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood disorder that results in the overproduction of red blood cells. It can cause headaches, dizziness, tinnitus, chest pain, and an enlarged spleen.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroid hormone. It can cause palpitations, unintentional weight loss, and nervousness.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia, a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. People with this condition may experience tinnitus and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body produces too many platelets, leading to a risk of thrombosis. Symptoms can include headaches, dizziness, chest pain, and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. It can cause lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and bruising or bleeding easily.

diagnoses.name: Heart Valve Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition in which one or more of the valves in the heart doesn't function properly, leading to disrupted blood flow. Symptoms can include chest pain and palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as mono, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms can include fatigue, sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and, in some cases, spleen enlargement.

diagnoses: Vitamin deficiency (e.g., B12, Vitamin A deficiency)
Sinusitis (Acute or Chronic depending on duration of symptoms)
Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) - associated with glycemic lability
Insulin Resistance - related to glycemic lability
Adenomyosis - considering the presence of Endometriosis
Chronic Fatigue Syndrome - considering the systemic impact of chronic pain and potential immune system involvement with sinusitis
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) - often comorbid with Endometriosis
Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - considering glycemic lability
Hypothyroidism - considering its potential to exacerbate or be associated with symptoms of endometriosis, sinusitis, and glycemic lability

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially causing dyslipidemia and, less commonly, vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss, often accompanied by tinnitus and sometimes nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including severe headaches, nausea, vomiting, and temporary sensorial disturbances such as tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction or side effect
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to medications can cause a variety of symptoms including vomiting, tinnitus, dysgeusia (altered taste), and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Acute kidney failure
diagnoses.description: A sudden loss of kidney function that can lead to a build-up of waste products in the blood, causing symptoms like vomiting and less frequently dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes episodes of severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the digestive system, which could explain vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause angioedema, vomiting, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes accompanied by other issues like tinnitus if there are complications or associated dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain that can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes other symptoms like vomiting due to pressure effects.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs, potentially leading to a variety of symptoms including dysgeusia and dyslipidemia.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Toxic Reaction to Bites or Stings
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Asthma (in the context of an acute exacerbation)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Environmental allergies (pollen, dust mites, molds, animal dander)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly after exposure to an allergen.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling in various body parts, including the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airways.

diagnoses.name: Carbohydrate Malabsorption
diagnoses.description: A condition where the intestine cannot properly absorb certain sugars, leading to abdominal cramps, diarrhoea, and often rhinorrhea due to concurrent food allergies.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic gastrointestinal disorder characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, and altered bowel habits, including instances of incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells, leading to a wide range of symptoms including flushing, abdominal cramps, and in severe cases, anaphylactoid reactions.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergies
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include digestive problems, hives, flushed skin, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Various medications can cause side effects including abdominal cramps, flushing, incontinence, and rhinorrhea, depending on the mechanism of action and individual susceptibilities.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many systems in the body, sometimes causing similar symptoms such as rhinorrhea (due to SLE-related sinusitis), abdominal cramping, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome resulting from a type of cancerous tumor that leads to an overproduction of certain chemicals in the body, causing flushing, abdominal cramping, and in severe cases, diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Neuroendocrine Tumors
diagnoses.description: A group of tumors affecting the neuroendocrine cells. Some of these tumors can secrete hormones that cause symptoms including flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, often accompanied by nausea and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain that can cause symptoms such as nausea, weakness, and difficulty with speech.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing symptoms such as weakness and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, caused by infection or an autoimmune response. Symptoms can include weakness, aphasia, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include nausea, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Ischemic Attack, Transient (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), resulting in weakness, nausea, and in severe cases, speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It can cause episodes of aphasia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hyponatremia
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the level of sodium in your blood is abnormally low, causing symptoms like nausea, weakness, and in some cases, confusion or speech problems.

diagnoses: Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) with involvement of the posterior circulation

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (scotoma) and other sensory symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness and dysarthria (difficulty in speaking).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it presents with temporary stroke-like symptoms such as weakness and dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include weakness and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, vomiting, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, causing symptoms including headache, vomiting, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection, with symptoms like headache, vomiting, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by extremely high blood pressure that leads to swelling in the brain, presenting symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain, symptoms can include severe headache, vomiting, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms but is often characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type headache
diagnoses.details: The most common type of headache, which feels like a constant ache or pressure around the head, especially at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster headache
diagnoses.details: A type of headache that is short-lived but extremely painful, occurring in clusters for a period of time followed by periods of remission.

diagnoses.name: Medication overuse headache
diagnoses.details: Headaches caused or worsened by the overuse of medication to treat headache symptoms. Often occurs in individuals who use headache pain relievers more than two or three days a week.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation of the sinuses that can cause a headache and other symptoms such as nasal congestion and facial pressure.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. It can cause severe headaches, fever, and a stiff neck, and can be life-threatening.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain, which can cause headaches, weakness, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.details: A form of stroke caused by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain, leading to a sudden severe headache, often described as the 'worst headache ever,' alongside other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial hypertension
diagnoses.details: Increased pressure inside the skull, which can lead to headaches, vision problems, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, resulting in pallor and weariness, which can include symptoms like headache and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and weakness in the face, arm, or leg.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that's preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances called aura. These can include flashes of light, blind spots, and other vision changes or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary greatly and include headaches, seizures, vomiting, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and weakness or loss of sensation in limbs.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: Meniere's Disease affects the inner ear and can cause vertigo along with hearing loss and tinnitus. It's a chronic condition that can lead to severe dizziness and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system that interrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. It can cause episodes of dizziness, aphasia, and weakness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Certain types of seizures may present with symptoms like those described.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, vomiting, confusion, seizures, and problems with speech or vision.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition occurs when the blood flow to the back of the brain is reduced, leading to symptoms such as dizziness, vertigo, double vision, slurred speech, and imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: This is bleeding that occurs inside the skull. Symptoms can include sudden headache, vomiting, vision changes, loss of balance or coordination, confusion, seizure, or weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C associated cryoglobulinemia)
Viral Infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr Virus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system becomes hyperactive and attacks normal, healthy tissue.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that causes the premature destruction of red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome that is caused by certain prescription drugs.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder in which the immune system destroys the body's red and white blood cells, as well as platelets.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious Anemia
diagnoses.description: A decrease in red blood cells when the body can't absorb enough vitamin B-12.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Felty's syndrome
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
Viral infections (e.g., Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr Virus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with pleural effusion due to serositis, neuropsychiatric symptoms including seizures and psychosis, skin manifestations like postinflammatory dyspigmentation, and hematological abnormalities such as lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can involve multiple organ systems, leading to lymphopenia, pleural effusions, and skin manifestations. Neurosarcoidosis can manifest as seizures or other neurological issues.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.rationale: TB can lead to pleural effusion, postinflammatory dyspigmentation following skin involvement (lupus vulgaris), lymphopenia, and in rare cases, central nervous system involvement including seizures and psychosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS can cause lymphopenia, pleural effusions (due to opportunistic infections), cutaneous manifestations, and neurological complications such as seizures and psychosis (due to opportunistic infections or HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders).

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Lymphomas can cause pleural effusion, lymphopenia (from bone marrow involvement or autoimmune phenomena), psychological symptoms due to systemic illness or direct CNS involvement, and rarely seizures if the central nervous system is involved.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can result in pleural effusions from pulmonary involvement, skin changes including pigmentation issues, along with less commonly neurological manifestations and hematological abnormalities like lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behcet's disease can cause neurological symptoms including seizures and psychosis, pleural effusions in rare cases, and various skin lesions that could potentially include post-inflammatory dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Some medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome presenting with pleural effusion, seizures, psychosis, lymphopenia, and skin manifestations similar to those in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., ANCA-associated vasculitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitis can involve pleural effusions, central nervous system manifestations including seizures and psychiatric disorders, and may cause cutaneous manifestations and lymphopenia depending on the type and severity of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.rationale: Neurosyphilis can present with seizures and psychosis. Though less directly associated with the other symptoms, secondary syphilis can have skin manifestations, and tertiary syphilis can involve organ systems leading potentially to pleural effusions and hematological changes.
